# 02. The Basics

## 005. Web Application Basics

- By the end of this Web Application Basics lecture, you'll learn what a web application is, how it works, and the various components that are involved in the web application communication
- A web application is any software application, whose services can be accessed via Web
  - for example,
    - When you're accessing Udemy, the Udemy developers have already developed a web application, and they've deployed it onto a `Web Server`, that can be accessed from a `Web Client`
    - So your browser sends a request to the server on which Udemy is running, and then the server will run the appropriate resources to serve your request, then server takes the response and send it back to you (web Client)
- The communication between a web client and a web server takes place using the HTTP
- `HTTP` stands for Hyper Text Transfer Protocol
  - it is a set of rules that makes it easy and the web client & web server should follow in order to communicate
- As web client follows HTTP, it can be called as HTTP client
- Examples of web-servers are Apache and IIS
- Examples of web-clients/web-browsers are Internet Explorer, Chrome, Safari, Firefox, etc.
- You can also develop a HTTP client in any programming language of your choice using the API it provides
- Popular websites or Popular web-applications include Google, facebook, twitter and bharaththiippireddy.com which is course creator's website
- To access a website, you use a `URL`, which stands for `Uniform Resource Locator`
  - it comprises of
    - a protocol such as `http://`
    - followed by a domain name or the server name, such as `udemy.com`
    - followed by a port number, such as `80`, but we rarely specify a port number explicitly because port 80 is the default port on which most of the web-servers run or port 80 is the default port for HTTP
      - Even if you don't specify any port number, web-browsers will by default connect on port 80
      - Web-Servers run by default on port 80, and web-browsers connect to the port 80 and then ask for the resources

## 006. Server Side Programming

- You'll learn about the various duties of a server-side program
- Every server-side program which runs on a web-container or a server like Apache Tomcat, Oracle WebLogic, IBM WebSphere, will
  1. Capture the user input: take or handle the request that comes from the client, capturing the user input that client is sending
  2. Communicate with the database: it then connects/communicates with the database
  3. Processing of data: whatever data/response comes back from database, web-server will handle it, see if there are any exceptions, or errors and if right data comes back or any operation such as update/delete went through successfully
  4. Produce a response page: it'll produce the response page, a dynamic HTML page/response is created on-the-fly depending on if there are any errors/exceptions and the operation in request went through properly or not
  5. Handing the response page to the server: web-server will simply hand the response to the web-browser

- These are the duties of any server-side program that you're writing, whether it is written in Java using Servlets, JSPs, or it is .NET or python

## 007. What and Why Django

- You'll learn what Django is and why we should use it
- Django is a web-application development framework
- Using Django we can develop a complete web-application by doing all the server-side programming, and we run our application on a Django server
- Once we have our application running,
  1. when a user request comes in from a web-browser,
  2. the Django server will take that request,
  3. invoke the appropriate component inside our web-application, and
  4. whatever the response that component gives,
  5. the Django server takes the response and sends it back to the client/browser

1. Not only that, Django offers a lot of super cool features that so that the application development is super `quick`
2. Once we have our requirements set, Django has a lot of inbuilt things that we can readily use, so it comes `fully-loaded`
3. We can use Django ORM, content administration, RSS feeds, All these features are there in Django already, we need not redevelop them
4. When it comes to `security`, Django again has a lot of things
    - it prevents SQL injection
    - it has inbuilt support for Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), authentication and authorization, we we'll learn later on
    - So, our application need not worry about all those, we simply configure them, and they're ready to use
5. Django applications are easy to `scale`, that is as our application is used by millions & millions of users, one single application running on a server cannot take care of all those requests
    - So, we can easily scale the application by deploying it to multiple Django servers as required
6. Django is very `versatile`, meaning it can be used to develop any kind of application, which could be a hospital-management application, it could be a simple e-commerce website, it could be a content management application or something else
    - This versatility gives Django such a good clientele, as it is used by many clients such as YouTube, Google, Instagram, and even NASA

- If you want to know more about Django, you can always go to [djangoproject.com](https://www.djangoproject.com), which is the official website

## 008. MVT Pattern

- Django uses the `MVT` design pattern, where
  - `M` stands for the Model component,
  - `V` for the View component and
  - `T` for the Template component
- No matter how many Django applications you create, you'll be organizing your code across these three components
- When a user request comes from the web-browser to our application running on a Django server, the Django server will hand that request over to a particular view
- It knows which request corresponds to which view, based on the configuration information we provide in the `urls.py`
- Once the view takes the request,
- It'll then process it using a model
  - if there are database interactions that are required, the model component is responsible for performing the CRUD operations against a database
- The view will then take whatever the model gives and hands it over to a template that will render the response back to the web-browser

- ![django-MVT-flow.png](data:image/png;base64,)

- The template component is where all the HTML lives, it'll also have some dynamic tags that DJango provides which are reponsible for rendering the final output

> So, we'll be writing all our logic inside `View`, the `View` is responsible for processing the incoming requests using the `Model`, then using the `Template` to render a response back

- If you're aware of the `MVC (Model View Controller)` design pattern, here
  - there is no controller, the Django server itself acts like a controller
  - the advantage of using this MVT design pattern is easy maintainance
- So, if there are any issues once our application goes into production,
  - if it is a database related issue, we can directly look at the `Model` component
  - if it is a business logic related issue, we look at `Views` and fix it right there
  - if it is a rendering issue, the output is not showing up correctly on the web-browser, we know where to look in the `Templates`
- Another advantage is reuse, we can use the same Model or the same Views or the same Templates across our applications and across our projects
- Simply remember that Django uses the MVT design pattern, wwhich we'll be using throughout this course

## 009. Django Projects and Applications

- Every Django project is a collection of multiple Django applications
- We'll not put all the code into one single huge project, but we'll divide our project into multiple applications
- We'll first create a project, then create multiple applications inside the project as we'll see in the next few lectures
- for example
  - if you're building a Patient management application/project
    - You'll divide all this into `Patient Clinicals`, `Patient Registration`, `Patient Claims` applications
    - so, You'll create a patient management project, but under that project you'll create three different applications
  - Similarly, if you're working on a flight reservation system, then you'll create a flight reservation project under which you'll have `Flight Reservation` and `Flight Checkin` applications
- The main advantage of this is reusability and maintainance of code, we can `reuse` the same application in other projects very easily, we can plug it wherever required
- Instead of having one huge codebase, we can easily maintain it, if we have an issue then we can directly look into the application where the issue is happening

> **Remember:** A Django project is a combination of multiple applications and some configuration.
Without a Django project we cannot create Django applications, we need to first create a Django project and then Django application
